states.label: Professional Competence
states.definition: The state of possessing adequate knowledge, skill, and experience to perform engineering work in a specific domain
states.source_text: Engineer A, as an experienced environmental engineer, was competent to analyze groundwater monitoring data

states.label: Direction and Control
states.definition: The state where an engineer maintains supervisory authority over work products and their development
states.source_text: the final document remained under Engineer A's direction and control

states.label: Responsible Charge Deficiency
states.definition: The state of failing to maintain adequate professional oversight and engagement in the engineering process
states.source_text: Engineer A did not maintain responsible charge in violation of licensure law

states.label: Technology Acceptance
states.definition: The state where a professional community acknowledges new tools as legitimate aids to practice
states.source_text: BER has a long history of open and welcome advocacy for the introduction of new technologies

states.label: Regulatory Uncertainty
states.definition: The state where no clear guidelines exist for a specific professional practice
states.source_text: at the time of the BER's review of this case there is no universal guideline mandating AI disclosure
